Award.AbstractNarration: Dr. de la Iglesia is one of four investigators who have organized a Chronobiology Workshop that will take place on October 29, 2013 in Mendoza, Argentina, one day before the XII Latin American Symposium of Chronobiology (XII LASC). This Workshop will bring together Latin American (Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico and Uruguay) and US Chronobiology researchers to discuss and challenge the latest ideas in the field and to promote future international collaborations. Chronobiology has grown tremendously in the last decade in Latin American countries, particularly Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Mexico. In most cases, research teams are headed by Principal Investigators who were trained in the US or Europe and who have returned to their home countries to establish independent research laboratories. Exposure of US and European research teams to projects taking place in Latin America offers a unique opportunity to foster intellectual and ethnic diversity, to achieve access to new biological models, and to develop strong academic links. Latin American upper-undergraduate, graduate and postodoctoral students will participate in the Workshop and in a specially designed Chronobiology course that will be held the day before the Workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to provide support for an international Workshop on Chronobiology. This discipline studies biological rhythms and clocks. NSF funding allowed covering the transportation, lodging and per diem expenses of eight US experts in this field who travelled to Mendoza, Argentina. The organization of the Workshop took advantage of the XII Latin American Symposium on Chronobiology, and took place immediately before this event. This allowed the US participants from several renowned universities (UCSD, Michigan State University, University of Michigan, University of Washington, Washington University and John Hopkins) to interact with over 140 students and colleagues from several Latin American Countries, including Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Uruguay. The official language of the Workshop was English, giving a unique opportunity to Latin American students to practice what has become the international language for the sciences. The Workshop offered plenty of time for open discussions and it was considered a great success by all parts involved.

As a result of the Workshop, several US researchers were exposed to a new research community, as well as to a new culture. Thus, the Workshop enabled new interactions that would have otherwise not been possible. Indeed, several laboratories have developed collaborations that involve either Latin American students traveling to US labs, US researchers visiting laboratories in Latin America, or simply the exchange of expertise and research tools.
